Afghan Girl is a 1984 photographic portrait of Sharbat Gula ( شربت ګله‎) (born c. 1972), also known as Sharbat Bibi, taken by photojournalist Steve McCurry. It appeared on the June 1985 cover of National Geographic. The image is of an adolescent girl with green eyes in a red headscarf looking intensely at the camera. The identity of the photo's subject was not initially known, but in early 2002, she was identified as Sharbat Gula. She was a Pashtun child living in the Nasir Bagh refugee camp in Pakistan during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan when she was photographed.

@yabee- Or better yet, this can be interpreted as Shindol's fantasy as to what could have happened in that situation, but with a different cast of characters, of course. You could imagine the potential backlash if he had done otherwise. Either way, it's not a new thing for stories of any kind to be based off a real-life event.

@yabee- That was pretty much self-evident. I can almost guarantee you that he wasn't even trying to hide the fact that it was based off of that event. I mean, the prize-winning photo is exactly the same. There are no mysterious parallels to be drawn, for it's based on the same situation with different characters. I know people have different triggers, but damn...take a deep breath, buddy. It's nothing to raise your blood-pressure over. Surprised you kept the score at 10/10, though. That, at least, I can agree with.

i hate this so much. Not for the pedophilia or sticking out womb shit, but the fact that this whole thing is literally just a r18 about steve mccurry, a real life photographer.

both photographers (mccurry and fuckboy in this manga);
- go to wartorn places for snapshots
- take a picture of a girl in a wartorn place
- said picture makes them famous
- the girl they take a picture of later meets them again in the future (though the difference is mccurry searched for his girl, in this case the cute girl came lookin for the fuckboy)

i dont know how to feel about any of this. 10/10, made me extremely upset to read as i realized the parallels.
